citing_paper_authors: Amit, Goyal | Hal, Daumé III | Suresh, Venkatasubramanian
raw_text: Language modeling (Chen and Goodman, 1996), noun-clustering (Ravichandran et al, 2005), constructing syntactic rules for SMT (Galley et al, 2004), and finding analogies (Turney, 2008) are examples of some of the problems where we need to compute relative frequencies
clean_text: Language modeling (Chen and Goodman, 1996), noun-clustering (Ravichandran et al, 2005), constructing syntactic rules for SMT (Galley et al, 2004), and finding analogies (Turney, 2008) are examples of some of the problems where we need to compute relative frequencies.

raw_text: An alternative embedding is that used by Turney (2008) in his PairClass system (see Section 6)
clean_text: An alternative embedding is that used by Turney (2008) in his PairClass system (see Section 6).

raw_text: Turney (2008) has recently proposed a simpler SVM-based algorithm for analogical classification called PairClass
clean_text: Turney (2008) has recently proposed a simpler SVM-based algorithm for analogical classification called PairClass.

raw_text: Turney (2008) argues that many NLP tasks can be formulated in terms of analogical reasoning, and he applies his PairClass algorithm to a number of problems including SAT verbal analogy tests ,synonym/antonym classification and distinction between semantically similar and semantically associated words
clean_text: Turney (2008) argues that many NLP tasks can be formulated in terms of analogical reasoning, and he applies his PairClass algorithm to a number of problems including SAT verbal analogy tests, synonym/antonym classification and distinction between semantically similar and semantically associated words.

citing_paper_authors: Gintarè, Grigonytè | João Paulo, Cordeiro | Gaël, Dias | Rumen, Moraliyski | Pavel, Brazdil
raw_text: Finally, (Turney, 2008) proposes a super vised machine learning approach for discovering synonyms, antonyms, analogies and associations. For that purpose, feature vectors are based on frequencies of patterns and classified by a SVM
clean_text: Finally, (Turney, 2008) proposes a supervised machine learning approach for discovering synonyms, antonyms, analogies and associations. For that purpose, feature vectors are based on frequencies of patterns and classified by a SVM.

citing_paper_authors: Gintarè, Grigonytè | João Paulo, Cordeiro | Gaël, Dias | Rumen, Moraliyski | Pavel, Brazdil
raw_text: In particular, (Turney, 2008) tackled the problem of classifying different lexical information such as synonymy ,antonymy ,hypernymy and association by using context words
clean_text: In particular, (Turney, 2008) tackled the problem of classifying different lexical information such as synonymy, antonymy, hypernymy and association by using context words.

citing_paper_authors: Yuval, Marton | Ahmed, El Kholy | Nizar, Habash
raw_text: Turney (2008) proposed a supervised method to solve word analogy questions that require identifying synonyms, antonyms, hyper nyms, and other lexical-semantic relations between word pairs
clean_text: Turney (2008) proposed a supervised method to solve word analogy questions that require identifying synonyms, antonyms, hypernyms, and other lexical-semantic relations between word pairs.

raw_text: Turney (2008) recently advocated the need for a uniform approach to corpus-based semantic tasks
clean_text: Turney (2008) recently advocated the need for a uniform approach to corpus-based semantic tasks.

raw_text: Such tasks will re quire an extension of the current framework ofTurney (2008) beyond evidence from the direct co occurrence of target word pairs
clean_text: Such tasks will require an extension of the current framework of Turney (2008) beyond evidence from the direct co-occurrence of target word pairs.

raw_text: Turney (2008) presents a general approach for classifying word pairs into semantic relations by extracting the strings occurring between the two words of a pair (up to three words in-between, up to one word on either side) and using a frequency-based selection process to select sub-patterns where words from the extracted context pattern may have been replaced by a wild card
clean_text: Turney (2008) presents a general approach for classifying word pairs into semantic relations by extracting the strings occurring between the two words of a pair (up to three words in-between, up to one word on either side) and using a frequency-based selection process to select sub-patterns where words from the extracted context pattern may have been replaced by a wild card.

raw_text: Building on a recent proposal in this direction by Turney (2008), we propose a generic method of this sort, and we test it on a set of unrelated tasks, reporting good performance across the board with very little task-specific tweaking
clean_text: Building on a recent proposal in this direction by Turney (2008), we propose a generic method of this sort, and we test it on a set of unrelated tasks, reporting good performance across the board with very little task-specific tweaking.

raw_text: Tasks of this sort differ from relation extraction in that we need to capture productive patterns: we want to find out that shabu shabu (a Japanese meat dish) is eaten whereas ink is not, even if in our corpus neither noun is attested in proximity to forms of the verb to eat. Turney (2008) is the first, to the best of our knowledge, to raise the issue of a unified approach
clean_text: Turney (2008) is the first, to the best of our knowledge, to raise the issue of a unified approach.

raw_text: The correct answer is the choice pair which has the relationship most similar to that in the stem pair. We adopt a similar approach to the one used in Turney (2008) and consider each question as a separate bi nary classification problem with one positive training instance and 5 unknown pairs
clean_text: We adopt a similar approach to the one used in Turney (2008) and consider each question as a separate bi nary classification problem with one positive training instance and 5 unknown pairs.

raw_text: The algorithm pro posed by Turney (2008) is labeled as Turney-PairClass
clean_text: The algorithm proposed by Turney (2008) is labeled as Turney-PairClass.

raw_text: This type of similarity is reminiscent of relational analogies investigated in Turney (2008)
clean_text: This type of similarity is reminiscent of relational analogies investigated in Turney (2008).

raw_text: Turney (2008) proposes a unified approach to handling analogies, synonyms, antonyms and associations by transforming the last three cases into cases of analogy
